title: When Is a Child Ready to Move to the Next Soroban Level?
description: How to know if your student has truly mastered a level versus just "getting it."
imageAlt: Child advancing to new soroban level

content.intro: "They got it right once, let's move on." This is how skill gaps form. Here's how to really know when a child is ready to advance.

rows: Gets it right most of the time

sections.text: You should move to the next level when there's MASTERY, not just understanding.

items: 95%+ accuracy over multiple sessions (not just one good day)
Speed is consistent, not fluctuating wildly
Can explain the concept to someone else
Bored with current level (good bored, not frustrated bored)
Speed is much slower than it should be
Gets anxious when problems are shuffled (not in order)
Can do it today but forgets tomorrow
Relies on counting beads one by one

sections.text: Moving too fast creates weak foundations. When they hit advanced concepts, everything falls apart.

If they can do a level well today, wait 2-3 days without practice. Then test again. If they're still accurate and fast, they've truly internalized it. This tests for real learning vs. short-term memory.

rows: 95% accuracy, instant recognition of 1-4 on soroban
No hesitation on complement pairs, 95% accuracy
No place value errors, consistent speed
Can visualize clearly, 80%+ accuracy eyes closed

sections.text: What to Do While Waiting for Mastery
"More practice on the same level" sounds boring. Mix it up:

items: Different problem formats (horizontal, vertical, word problems)
Reverse problems (given answer, find the problem)
Teach a younger sibling or stuffed animal
Mix current level with review of previous levels

faq.question: What if they're really frustrated staying at one level?
faq.answer: Try a "preview" of the next level – just to see it, no pressure. Then return to mastery. Seeing what's coming can motivate pushing through the current level.

faq.question: My app advances them automatically – should I trust it?
faq.answer: Most good apps require demonstrated mastery before advancing. But if your child seems shaky, there's nothing wrong with manually repeating levels.

faq.question: Is there such thing as too much time at one level?
faq.answer: If they're getting 95%+ consistently for 2+ weeks and still not advancing, yes, move up. Overmastery has diminishing returns.

cta.text: SoroKid uses mastery-based progression – children advance only when truly ready.
